content.value_statement: Managing multiple AI agents in parallel creates coordination complexity. This skill provides exact prompts and workflows for coordinating agent swarms through NTM, Agent Mail, Beads, and BV tools.
actual_capabilities: Coordinates multiple AI agents through the Agent Mail messaging system
Uses BV tool for intelligent task prioritization and bead selection
Manages file reservations to prevent merge conflicts between agents
Provides exact prompts for initial swarm startup and ongoing task progression
Implements quality review loops with self-review, cross-review, and exploration phases
limitations: Requires pre-configured AGENTS.md file and running Agent Mail server
Does not install or configure NTM, Agent Mail, Beads, or BV tools
Assumes users understand the planning and beads creation phases first
Does not provide actual agent code execution environment

use_cases.title: Launch Parallel Development Teams
use_cases.description: Start a swarm of 3-6 AI agents working on the same codebase with coordination via Agent Mail and task prioritization through BV.
use_cases.target_user: Engineering leads coordinating large feature development

use_cases.title: Implement Complex Multi-File Changes
use_cases.description: Break down large refactoring tasks across multiple agents that coordinate through file reservations and bead tracking.

use_cases.title: Run Quality Assurance Sprints
use_cases.description: Deploy agents for systematic code review, bug hunting, and UI/UX enhancement passes with coordinated quality loops.
use_cases.target_user: QA engineers conducting thorough code audits

prompt_templates.title: Initial Agent Marching Orders
prompt_templates.prompt:
First read ALL of the AGENTS dot md file and README dot md file super carefully and understand ALL of both! Then use your code investigation agent mode to fully understand the code, and technical architecture and purpose of the project. Then register with MCP Agent Mail and introduce yourself to the other agents.

Be sure to check your agent mail and to promptly respond if needed to any messages; then proceed meticulously with your next assigned beads, working on the tasks systematically and meticulously and tracking your progress via beads and agent mail messages.

When you're not sure what to do next, use the bv tool mentioned in AGENTS dot md to prioritize the best beads to work on next. Use ultrathink.
prompt_templates.scenario: Starting a new swarm session with all agents

prompt_templates.title: Move to Next Bead
prompt_templates.prompt: Reread AGENTS dot md so it's still fresh in your mind. Use ultrathink. Use bv with the robot flags to find the most impactful bead(s) to work on next and then start on it. Remember to mark the beads appropriately and communicate with your fellow agents. Pick the next bead you can actually do usefully now and start coding on it immediately. And respond to any agent mail messages you've received.
prompt_templates.scenario: Agent completed a bead and needs next task

prompt_templates.title: Self-Review After Changes
prompt_templates.prompt: Great, now I want you to carefully read over all of the new code you just wrote and other existing code you just modified with fresh eyes looking super carefully for any obvious bugs, errors, problems, issues, confusion, etc. Carefully fix anything you uncover. Use ultrathink.
prompt_templates.scenario: Agent completed a bead and should review their own work

prompt_templates.title: Cross-Agent Code Review
prompt_templates.prompt: Ok can you now turn your attention to reviewing the code written by your fellow agents and checking for any issues, bugs, errors, problems, inefficiencies, security problems, reliability issues, etc. and carefully diagnose their underlying root causes using first-principle analysis and then fix or revise them if necessary? Don't restrict yourself to the latest commits, cast a wider net and go super deep! Use ultrathink.
prompt_templates.scenario: Quality review phase with agents reviewing each other's work

output_examples.input: I have 4 Claude Code agents and 2 Codex agents. How do I start them?
output_examples.output:
Use NTM to spawn the swarm:

ntm spawn myproject --cc=4 --cod=2

Then send the Initial Marching Orders prompt to all agents:
ntm send myproject --all "[Initial prompt text]"

output_examples.input: Two agents want to edit the same file. How do we prevent conflicts?
output_examples.output:
Before editing, each agent must reserve files:

1. Call file_reservation_paths with exclusive=True
2. Announce via send_message to other agents
3. After completing work, release_file_reservations

The pre-commit guard enforces file reservations.

output_examples.input: How do agents know which bead to work on next?
output_examples.output:
Use the bv tool with robot flags:

bv --robot-triage  # Full analysis
bv --robot-next    # Get single top pick
bv --robot-plan    # Parallel execution tracks

These prioritize ready beads by impact and dependency order.

best_practices: Configure AGENTS.md with all tool blurps before starting the swarm
Keep the Agent Mail server running throughout the entire session
Run quality review loops until agents consistently return no changes
Use file reservations before editing any shared codebase
anti_patterns: Running bare bv command without robot flags - it launches blocking TUI
Letting agents get stuck in communication purgatory without making progress
Skipping the self-review phase after bead completion
Running agents without pre-configured AGENTS.md and tool blurps

faq.question: How do agents know what to work on?
faq.answer: Agents use bv --robot-triage or bv --robot-next to find the highest-impact ready bead based on the bead dependency graph.

faq.question: How do agents avoid conflicts?
faq.answer: File reservations in Agent Mail provide exclusive access. The pre-commit guard enforces reservations and prevents overlapping edits.

faq.question: What if an agent crashes or forgets?
faq.answer: Every agent is fungible and a generalist. Start a new session, read AGENTS.md, check bead status via bv, and continue from where the previous agent left off.

faq.question: How many agents should I run?
faq.answer: Depends on project complexity. Start with 3-6 agents. More agents means faster completion but more coordination overhead.

faq.question: Do agents need individual areas of expertise?
faq.answer: No, every agent is fungible and a generalist using the same base model. Simply telling one it is a frontend agent does not make it better at frontend.

faq.question: What tools are required before starting?
faq.answer: You need NTM for session management, Agent Mail server running, BV for task prioritization, and a pre-configured AGENTS.md file with all tool blurps.
